entry.title: First Week of Work for Northwood Publications, Inc

content.p: I just got a project done for my new job, part time assistant with Northwood Publications, Inc. The employer is John Marco. I have had e-mail correspondence with him and maybe at some point we'll get to meet.
He gave me a list of ISBNs and wanted prices for them. I got data from bookfinder.com . I did the processing on Linux. I had to scrape HTML. The gorey details follow.
Just did a google and found bookfinder.com . Would liked to have had access to Bowker's Books in Print, and e-mailed Mr. Marco about it, but that wasn't in the cards.
Bookfinder's results are sorted lowest price first. Where there were multi-part result sets, I just need the overview page of data. Each page is broken down into new, used and rental books.
I used awk to parse the URLs and generate tsv files. I used 'q' to generate results.
I just went to the after-party at Rowhouse. We had a blast, especially once the dancing started.
I'm slowly reconnecting with these folks, even many I didn't connect with in high school. This is a great class I was involved with and I really should think about going to senior trip redux.
I have been using dropbox to host "Sadie's Cookbook," a collection of recipes from Sadie Schoss's recipe card box using JSON for storage.

It orginally had one static file for each recipe. Every time a new recipe was called it would take more or less of a long time for the HTML to load, depending on the connection. I eventually came around to the idea of loading the data from one javascript file. I found a good javascript router to use and I chose what I consider the best of the javascript markdown converters.
The results are posted on github at http://github.com/trauber/sadies-cookbook .
Right now the recipes are in an array, meaning insertion or deletionb of a recipe will break any bookmarked routes. I need to key each recipe on its slug and use the slug for creating the routes.

The style of calendar I like has a page size image with text of a vertical calendar superimposed on it. Here's a sample of the calendar text, output from ncal -h.
For an image I'm using this photo of my dog Balou in a Chicago snowstorm,

For superimposing the calendar text I found two approaches. The first is to use ncal -h output and use a \verbatim environment. This turned out to be a little too fragile; it works for some fonts but not for many others. I found code at tex.stackexchange that uses the tikz package's calendar library. It has handled every font I've used with it.
As, provided, the tikz code produces this small calendar.

One of my favorite LaTeX packages is mathptmx . I haven't used LaTeX for math or science, but I have used it for work reports and for personal projects and I've always been interested in making custom title pages with fonts of various sizes. mathptmx enables use of extremely large fonts. Adding this package to the preamble and applying the \fontsize and \selectfont commands yields the same calendar in point 40 font.
content.h2: Combining Calendar Text and Page Size Image
content.p: I found two approaches for combining calendar and image. One is to use the LaTeX wallpaper package and to write the calendar over it. While this works it enforces lots of LaTeX's built-in heuristics for placing the calendar text. Another approach proved more flexible. The overpic package's \put command allows placing text over a picture with coordinates.
